ovdesc.p: This table stores the relationship between the National Clearing Code (NCC) and the BIC. This table would be used to convert a National ID to its corresponding BIC or vice versa.
Data for this table can be keyed in manually or can be uploaded from a file
Any manually keyedin record in the Bank code table is marked as manually updated.
The upload process does not overwrite records keyed in manually.

desc.p: Date and Time when the record was created in DD MON 2015 HH:MM:SS.MMM format
User ID of the record creator
Name of the financial institution or bank
Contains the BIC-11 issued together with the IBANs for the institution’s clients.
Institution code (4 characters)
Country code (2 characters)
Location code (2 characters)
Branch code (3 characters – XXX to denote head or main office)
Country code in the IBAN. This follows ISO 3166-1, contains only alphabets and is 2 character long.
Under certain circumstances this can be different from the country indicated in field Country Name
The National ID which is as part of the IBAN.
Standard T24 alphanumeric field.
The National identifier of the institution/branch otherwise called NCC(National Clearing Code)
The source from which details of bank code was updated.
Specifies whether this specific record can be overwritten when uploaded from a file.
To prevent data upload to overwrite this record, set this field to 'N'. Else, set it to 'Y'.
Date and Time when the record was approved in DD MON 2015 HH:MM:SS.MMM format
Record Activation Code generated for the record by the payment's hub.
Possible values:
N - Not active
A - Active
H - History
F - Future
C - Not active future
Record Status Code generated for the record by the payments hub.
Possible values:
L - Live
U - Unapproved
R - Reversed
This attribute links to the SourceKey in BICTable.
Specifies the date on which the record is to be considered active by the payments hub.
Post code of the institution/branch.
User ID of the record approver
Unique Identifier, system generated
Holds the unique BIC of the institution from the BIC directory.
Can be maximum of 11 characters. BIC comprises of
Institution code (4 characters)
Country code (2 characters)
Location code (2 characters)
Branch code (3 characters – XXX denotes main or head office)
This is applicable only for EMZ clearing. Every BLZ has a logic for validating the account number. This field stores the method for validating that BLZ code.
Name of the city where the institution/branch is located.
Indicates the company ID for which the record is created.
Example : BNK,GB1
The value links to the field ‘CompanyID’ in PPT.COMPANY
Denotes the country for which the National ID is defined
